user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_GetStubEntry:
```c
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_GetStubEntry:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef enum
{
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED,                 /**< Unused/available table entries */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_COUNTER,                /**< Records a usage count plus most recent return code */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER,            /**< Storage for data buffers to simulate read/write or queue ops */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALLBACK_HOOK,          /**< A custom callback/hook function to be invoked prior to handler */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALLBACK_CONTEXT,       /**< Context data for callback/hook function */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE,              /**< Records a "call once" directive */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER,          /**< The final handler for the stub */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER,          /**< Storage for actual return value from stub */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED, /**< Configuration for return value from stub */
    UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT, /**< Configuration for return value from stub */
} UT_EntryType_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
...
static uint32              UT_MaxStubSearchLen             = 0
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other constructs in the provided code are standard C language features and do not indicate the use of compiler-specific language extensions. Examples include: use of static functions/variables, enum definitions, typedefs for standard-width integers (uint32_t), array declarations and indexing, arithmetic and increment operators (++), modulo (%), while(1) loops, and the aggregate initializer {{0}} — each of these is standard C and not a compiler extension. No GCC/Clang-specific attributes (e.g. __attribute__), asm statements, typeof, statement-expressions, anonymous structs/unions, or other common compiler-only extensions are present in the shown code. The only item that could represent a non-standard/implementation-specific type is the cpuaddr identifier (hence the fragments above). Investigation should focus on whether cpuaddr is a compiler-provided extension (or macro/typedef to a standard type) by checking its definition and the compiler documentation; all other fragments need not be investigated for Rule 1.2.
